report_title: Margarine & Cooking Oil Processing in the US
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Margarine and cooking oil processors produce vegetable oil, shortening, margarine and starches for sale to food service establishments, food and energy producers, wholesalers and retailers. The industry grew volatile as input prices fluctuated heavily. Amid the pandemic, high prices of critical agricultural inputs drove revenue. Processors also encountered elevated demand for the industry's products, particularly nonperishable ones, in 2020 as the pandemic caused consumer stockpiling habits. Overall, revenue is anticipated to swell at a CAGR of 6.6 to $90.2 billion over the five years to 2024, despite a 2.7% dip in 2024 alone, as recovering agricultural inventories cause the industry's selling prices to drop.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Processors Adapt to Healthy Consumer Trends
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: It is recommended in the US Department of Agriculture's latest Dietary Guidelines for Americans that individuals limit their intake of saturate and trans-fatty acids to help lower the risk of coronary heart disease. Similarly, the link between fat consumption and obesity has turned consumers away from purchasing animal fats, like lard, stimulating the market for edible vegetable oils. Several companies, like Bunge, have invested in zero trans-fat product lines to appeal to shifting consumer trends.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Imports Play a Growing Role in the Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Foreign processors have jumped to satisfy the growing demand for healthier cooking oils. In particular, Spain and Italy are significant exporters of olive oil since the region offers prime olive growing conditions, making olives less expensive for processors. Similarly, Indonesia and Malaysia have chokeholds on the palm oil markets as the world's two largest palm farming countries. Indonesia, though, has cut palm oil exports to secure its domestic supply ahead of Ramadan.

Input costs skyrocketed in 2021 and 2022 following several supply chain disruptions, with the prices of oilseeds, corn and soybeans ballooning. The pandemic hampered international trade, making it more difficult for domestic manufacturers to source inputs. In 2022, the Russian invasion of Ukraine decimated the region's soybean and oilseed imports. Despite long-term supply contracts, processors faced massive purchasing cost increases. Since cooking oils are staple products, processors could easily pass added costs onto consumers, resulting in significant revenue and profit gains.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: PROCESSORS WILL ADAPT TO A CHANGING REGULATORY ENVIRONMENT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Local and state regulations plan to incentivize restaurants to use healthier cooking oils to encourage the widespread adoption of these healthier products. For example, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has banned food manufacturers from adding partially hydrogenated oils, which contain trans fats, to foods. The FDA and US Department of Agriculture (USDA) have also put out guidance regarding monosaturated fats, which could shape the future cooking oil and margarine processing landscape.

Shifting consumer demand toward organically grown inputs will propel product innovation within the industry. According to Bunge Limited, US consumers strongly oppose products made from genetically modified crops because of perceived links with health complications. Other countries also have regulations that limit or ban the sale of foods containing GMOs or require specific labeling, which raises costs for domestic processors. Many companies will shift to organically grown raw materials to access these international consumers and appeal to an expanding health-conscious consumer base domestically.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: E X P L O R I N G  N E W  H O R I Z O N S  I N  C U L I N A R Y  F L A V O R S
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The culinary world is set to embrace a broader spectrum of global flavors, with consumer demand for exotic and international tastes driving the creation of diverse products. A shift towards artisanal and small-batch margarine and cooking oil offerings reflects a growing appreciation for authenticity and craftsmanship in the culinary industry. Traditional cooking oils and margarine are transforming, incorporating innovative ingredients to craft distinctive and appealing flavor profiles for contemporary consumers.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry produce vegetable oil, shortening and margarine. Activities include wet milling corn and vegetables, crushing oilseeds and tree nuts, refining and blending vegetable oils and blending purchased animal fats with vegetable fats. The industry also includes starch production.
key_trends: Consumer preference for healthy alternatives drives innovation.
People are willing to pay premiums for quality, nutrient-rich products.
Brand loyalty is critical to maintaining market share, although its importance varies between product segments. Brand-loyal customers are less sensitive to price increases.
Margarine and cooking oil processors must adapt to changing consumer preferences. Processors have emphasized healthier cooking oils, like olive and avocado oil.

The industry will continue to face substantial price and product competition from foreign processors. Foreign producers dominate palm and olive oil production, two increasingly popular cooking oil and margarine options.

Successful processors are constantly adding new options through consolidation or product innovation. For example, Archer-Daniels-Midland has been highly active in the market, acquiring Harvest Innovations to bolster product lines.
Producers must follow stringent FDA guidelines and regulations
Rising input prices have put pressure on profit
Large companies have reduced wage costs through automation
Processors congregate near major inputs, cutting down on transportation costs
Processors will be located near key trading partners
Major companies leverage reputations into favorable contracts with downstream markets

market_segmentation.segment_description: Food manufacturers purchase margarine, oils and spreads to use as inputs for producing other goods, including cookies, beverages, prepared meals and other food products.

Grocery retailers represent the second-largest downstream market for the margarine and cooking oil processing industry. At-home eating trends also pushed households to purchase more cooking oils and margarine for meal preparation at grocery stores instead of eating out.

Food service providers represent the largest downstream market for the margarine and cooking oil Processing industry. Demand from fast food restaurants and other chain restaurants will mount as consumers seek affordable, convenient meals, especially as consumer confidence struggles to recover.

Grocery wholesalers and retailers represent the second-largest downstream market for the margarine and cooking oil processing industry. While some leading processors in this industry distribute their goods directly to downstream customers, smaller producers rely on independent wholesalers to distribute their products.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes the processing of corn oil and starches for food consumption; the industry excludes ethyl alcohol and laundry starch since these products are outside the scope of the industry's definition.
Food manufacturers use soybean oil as a critical input in salad dressing, margarine and processed foods.

Buyers also use soybean meal in livestock feed, which depends on livestock numbers and the prices of other feeds. Buyers also use soybean derivatives for various industrial applications, including coatings, inks, adhesives and oleo chemistry.

This segment includes crushing oilseeds and tree nuts, like cottonseed, linseeds, peanuts and sunflower seeds. Since this segment is well-diversified, gains in one sub-segment can offset declines in another.

tier_1_suppliers: Corn, Wheat & Soybean Wholesaling in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Seasoning, Sauce and Condiment Production in the US
Frozen Food Production in the US
Cookie, Cracker & Pasta Production in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Food Service Contractors in the US
Community Food Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Oilseeds, a key ingredient in producing numerous cooking oils and margarine, have seen a moderate price rally. This price hike positively impacts producers, allowing them to pass the augmented production costs to their downstream markets, like wholesalers and retailers. Significantly, this does not affect the overall demand from consumers, providing a sustained market for these products.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada is responsible for one of the most significant proportions of industry imports. The country has a booming agriculture sector because of its favorable climate, enabling it to be a global provider of oilseeds and related products. Most notably, Canada is a crucial canola oil producer, a healthy vegetable oil with a lower price point. Spain is also a significant exporter of olive oil, which, like canola oil, is low in saturated and trans fats but high in monosaturated fat.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The rising US dollar drives import demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: As the US dollar has appreciated, imports have grown inexpensively, making them a suitable alternative to more expensive domestic products. Even so, imports represent a small portion of total domestic demand. Demand for imports will subside as the US dollar depreciates. Price-sensitive consumers may avoid imports altogether.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) drives exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada and Mexico are significant export destinations because of their proximity to the United States and participation in USMCA. The USMCA keeps prices low even as the US dollar has strengthened relative to its trade partners. Mexico has mainly been a growing importer of cooking oil and margarine to support the country's rapidly growing population and food manufacturing industries.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Most major companies have overseas facilities
international_trade_points.trade_description: Many of the industry's significant companies own processing facilities internationally that supply foreign markets directly, bringing down the industry's overall export total. The US dollar has also appreciated over the past few years, piling onto weak exports. As this trend reverses, exports will blossom and support growth.

business_locations.location_description: The Plains region is a trendy cooking oil and margarine processing area because of its high number of soybean and oilseed farmers. The region is also near the Great Lakes, enabling processors to cut transportation costs to major manufacturing buyers.

The Southeast region is close to some of the nation's largest seaports, allowing processors to export freely to foreign countries like Mexico and Columbia. The region's high population also affords it a larger market than other regions, with easy access to major cities like Miami, Atlanta, Nashville and New Orleans. Manufacturers also take advantage of abundant labor in the region.

Processors are located near major metropolitan areas in the Great Lakes region. Detroit and Cleveland, for example, have many producers servicing the area. The region is also home to many other major food manufacturers. Companies will locate near these manufacturers to facilitate sales. Great Lakes manufacturers also benefit from trade with Canada, the industry's second-highest cooking oil and margarine importer. Also, major companies, like Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, have their headquarters in Illinois.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA ensures food safety, enforcing laws through inspections and legal actions under the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act. This includes compliance with labeling rules around ingredients, GMOs, origin and descriptions. For instance, vegetable oil spreads cannot be labeled as alternatives to butter or margarine unless they resemble those products and are not nutritionally inferior.

State and local governments often oversee food safety, working with federal agencies to implement food safety standards within their borders. They also conduct inspections for food manufacturing facilities to enforce hygiene standards and implement and enforce embargoes on food items that are unsafe for consumption.

The EPA addresses environmental issues and enforces ecological protection laws. The most relevant environmental laws in the industry include the Clean Water Act (CWA), Clean Air Act (CAA), Pollution Prevention Act and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). These statutes and laws determine how food manufacturers handle raw materials and dispose of waste.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Companies must follow strict legal guidelines. Processors must adhere to quality and labeling standards or risk recalls, fines and ruined reputations.

Major companies have established long-term agreements to supply large downstream customers in the food retailing and service industries. It's difficult for entrants to secure contracts with major buyers. Prospects still have the opportunity to enter the industry by introducing differentiated products, like healthy oils and spreads.

basis_points.basis_title: Consumer preference for healthy alternatives drives innovation
basis_points.basis_description: People are willing to pay premiums for quality, nutrient-rich products. Brand loyalty is critical to maintaining market share, although its importance varies between product segments. Brand-loyal customers are less sensitive to price increases.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Major companies dedicate resources to consolidation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Acquisition activity in this industry has been limited but will accelerate as major companies have more resources to dedicate to acquisitions. Archer-Daniels-Midland Company (ADM) has completed multiple critical acquisitions over the past decade. For example, in 2016, ADM acquired a controlling stake in Harvest Innovations, a producer of soy oils and proteins. Through acquisitions, ADM and other companies diversify their product offering and capture a more significant portion of the market.

The top two processors, Archer-Daniels-Midland and Bunge, account for over half of total revenue. These companies operate internationally, taking advantage of a wide variety of markets. Consumers often express strong brand loyalty to these companies, valuing high quality and consistency. Also, these companies leverage vertical integration to enhance operational efficiency.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Skyrocket as Global Supply Chains Contract
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The most significant industry cost is the purchase of raw materials, including oilseeds, soybeans and corn. Specifically, the prices of oilseeds and soybeans spiked as supply chains tightened during the pandemic. Also, the Russian invasion of Ukraine added to input volatility since Russia and Ukraine are two of the top oilseed exporters.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Operations are highly capital intensive, requiring human input for quality control and machine operation. Automation has eliminated the need for most labor-intensive jobs.

The industry relies on large-scale equipment like commercial crushing, refining equipment, grain bins and elevators. Labor often serves ancillary roles, like monitoring production lines or researching new products to appeal to shifting consumer preferences.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Oilseed and soy prices skyrocketed following the pandemic's onset. Despite many processors holding supply contracts with farmers, revenue volatility skyrocketed. The Russian invasion of Ukraine added to volatility, especially since the two countries are major soy and crude oil suppliers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: PROCESSORS FACE MAJOR CONSUMER PREFERENCE SHIFTS
volatility_points.volatility_description: As people search for healthier lifestyles, they have shifted their purchasing preferences. Many consumers avoid products with trans or saturated fats. Despite premium prices, this trend has precipitated growth in the avocado and sunflower oil markets. Companies have readily shifted production to meet demand.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many processors have focused on creating nutritional cooking oils and margarine. These products are often low in monosaturated fat and high in polyunsaturated fat. Coconut and avocado oils are prime examples of this trend.

Businesses refine production processes by introducing new machinery and adopting applied science. Often, processors have incorporated the latest technology to minimize costs while boosting operating efficiency. The adoption of new technology has been confined to the leading processors. Smaller companies lack the capital to upgrade to new technology.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: The United States is a net exporter of goods this industry produces. With rising climate change impacts worldwide, providing a steady and stable source of cooking oil can give producers a competitive edge and provide supplemental revenue when domestic sales are weak.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: With the rise of health consciousness among US consumers, companies in this industry have diversified their offerings of cooking oils to contain more producers that consumers would consider healthier, such as coconut and olive oils. These products are typically more expensive and may improve profit; however, demand for these specialty goods will likely suffer during economic downturns.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near key suppliers?
FAQs.answer: To minimize transportation costs, operators in this industry locate themselves near strategic sources of inputs, such as significant oilseed, soybean or corn growing areas. Manufacturers with greater control over their supply chains typically experience greater profitability and are less likely to suffer as frequently or severely from supply chain disruption.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Cooking oil producer revenue highly depends on the price of critical inputs. Corn and oilseed prices have increased over the past five years, boosting revenue. Companies that can secure low-price inputs now may earn more significant profit as prices and selling prices rise during the outlook period.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Margarine and cooking oil production requires costly machinery, so many producers allocate funds toward capital purchases. Wage costs can be mitigated by investing in automated technologies requiring fewer physical workers. However, such technologies are often price-prohibitive.

FAQs.question: Do you use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of your company's manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: Large cooking oil producers have already adopted computerized systems for managing customer and supplier arrangements, resulting in cost savings through better inventory and production planning.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The Corn Refiners Association, American Fats and Oils Association and the US Canola Association are the main associations supporting margarine and cooking oil producers.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly affected profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has in the past imposed civil penalties on certain operators in this industry for violations of the Clean Water Act. New workplace safety standards may lead to an increase in operating expense.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Adding more profitable product lines or secure low-cost inputs can help companies outperform industry peers. Securing a stable supply of inputs can help producers reduce volatility, gain a loyal customer base and boost profit.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects on the horizon that will require capital financing?
FAQs.answer: Margarine and cooking oil producers invest significantly in capital, so new plants or expansions often require outside financing. High interest rates typically deter producers from making costly expansions, as few can pay for such services in cash.

FAQs.question: How strong is your relationship with your input supplier? Do you have many input suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Successful companies secure contracts with suppliers of key inputs, especially soybeans and corn, to lock in prices and ensure a stable supply of raw goods. Guaranteed supplies at established prices help minimize purchase costs and assist production planning.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales comes from exports? Do you trade with any specific countries?
FAQs.answer: Successful companies seek to export industry-specific products to foreign markets to increase their overall market presence while also reducing exposure to any singular market.

FAQs.question: What opportunities are available to increase the scale of your business? Do you experience competition based on economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: Larger processors benefit from lower per unit costs due to efficiency gains achieved from economies of scale. Some industry players have acquired smaller companies as a means to improve economies of scale and reduce operating costs.

FAQs.question: How have falling corn prices affected your financial performance? How price elastic are your products and how do you sustain profit when input prices change significantly?
FAQs.answer: As the price of corn rises, operators can either pass on the cost increases to downstream customers or absorb the costs.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue is derived from food manufacturers? Do you plan to work with more food manufacturers in the future?
FAQs.answer: Food manufacturers use products from the Margarine and Cooking Oil Processing industry as inputs for their products.

FAQs.question: Does international trade play a significant role in your company's operations? Do you track changes in the trade-weighted index?
FAQs.answer: When the US dollar appreciates, domestic goods are relatively more expensive and imports' share of domestic demand increases.
